ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: As a non-film studies major, I definitely gained some basic film studies vocabulary and understanding. Also learned a lot about the German perspective on WWII and the generational effects of Nazism and the Holocaust. Definitely a great German culture course, or a history course (especially if you are interested in memory culture or WWII specifically).
I learned a tremendous amount about how to analyze films and, specifically, about how to responsibly represent the Third Reich and the Holocaust in film.
I learned how to view films analytically and I learned more about German history!

In addition to gaining a technical knowledge of filmic techniques and devices, I've left this course with a robust understanding of the ethical concerns involved in depicting the Third Reich through film.
Learnt a deep amount of third reich films and how they were representative of the German mindset.

I learned so much about German history, the Jewish experience in Nazi Germany, and the evolution of the German perspective on the nation's past and the world war. This course really opened my eyes to film as a medium through which history, culture, and change can be examined. As a history major, I definitely got what I wanted out of the course (more so than in actual history courses), and also developed a more sophisticated film vocabulary.

I learned a ton about basic film analysis as well as memory studies. Never having written a paper on a film before this class, I came out of it feeling confident in my ability to analyze individual scenes and overall themes in movies.
Third Reich and German history, critical film analysis

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: the grading structure is really excellent and conducive to a lot of different learning needs (you can either do weekly responses every week, or skip some and do a final paper). Prof. Hagens is very kind and invested in us as students and learners. 
Weaknesses: sometimes the films were a bit boring (in my opinion) or the discussions were too lecture heavy, but in general it was a really well-run seminar

This was a very well-designed course. Students were required to write a two-page analysis of each film each week in lieu of a final paper. But, if students choose, they could skip up to four weekly responses and instead write a final paper at the end of the semester. This provided students with several different options and allowed us to choose what was best for us. The readings and films were fascinating and class discussion was incredibly engaging.
This course is really good at engaging with the film I loved it
This course's strengths include an emphasis on discussion and its emphasis on the ethical component of filmmaking; I really can't think of any weaknesses.
Nothing should be changed, the course is great.

Purely strengths. This course was the best course I have taken at Yale so far. Prof. Hagens is an amazing, friendly professor and the workload was manageable and even exciting. The course was one I genuinely looked forward to and enjoyed doing the viewings and discussion contributions for.

The most obvious strength of the course is the content material. The required films are incredibly interesting and offer a range of German perspectives on culpability and the Third Reich. The format of the class, in which a student leads discussion on the film every week, was also very successful. The only weakness I might point out was that I sometimes wished we got to hear Prof. Hagens give more historical and filmic context in class.
Heavy on the film history. Although it was interesting, we could have examined filmic methods and analysis more.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely, especially as a German culture course or history course. Probably not a lot of new film studies info if you're a film studies major, but if you're not, it's a good intro film studies course!

Absolutely. Professor Hagens is a kind and engaging professor. The class content was fascinating. It is a discussion-based class, and the assignments were meant to force you to engage with the material as opposed to being arbitrary assignments. I learned so much and thoroughly enjoyed each and every class.
Absolutely it is a great course for beginners in film and history.

I would absolutely recommend this course, no matter what your major is, because it introduces students to questions such as memory, guilt, &c. that pervade the media we encounter on a day-to-day basis.
Yes 100% Professor Hagens is the best.
Yes absolutely.
Absolutely
I would absolutely recommend. Even if you aren't interested in German history or film, the course was an absolute joy to take.

I would recommend this course to anyone who enjoys movies or has interest in Germany and the Third Reich. It is not too demanding of a course but 
the material is tremendously engaging.
Take it if you are curious about German history and the way it intersects with memory, family, culture, and film.

extras.title: FILM 319 01/GMAN 273 01/LITR 368 01 - Third Reich in German Films
